awd_titl_txt: Strain-Mediated Activation of Skin Regeneration and Fibrosis
awd_abstract_narration:
Many amphibians can regrow entire limbs and organs, however, mammalian regeneration is essentially unheard of in the natural world. Recently, we have identified a remarkable mammal that has regenerative ability - the African Spiny Mouse (Acomys). Preliminary data from collaborations across our University are exciting and intriguing: Acomys tissues do not exhibit fibrosis (scarring) when repairing damage. After inducing injury to the skin, ear, heart, brain, and spinal cord, we find minimal, if any, fibrosis markers stereotypical of mammalian pathologies. Understanding fibrosis is the key to unlocking the secrets of regeneration. This research will test the hypothesis that mechanical stimuli can direct regeneration by providing controlled mechanical stimulation of cells from regenerative (Acomys) and normal (Mus) mice. If successful, we will have identified mechanisms to control scarring in adult mammals for the first time.

The long-term goal of the research is to identify the dominant mechanism of scar-free wound healing. We hypothesize that regenerative cells may not only be programmed to respond to injury differently but may also receive different physical signals. The key research objectives of this project are to (1) Establish the importance of mechanical tension cues on integrin expression and downstream signaling in cells from regenerative and fibrotic models, and (2) Define the role of white blood cells in mediating wound remodeling. Because the mechanical microenvironment of cells is so dissimilar in Acomys and Mus animals, we cannot investigate these hypotheses in vivo. Here, we control the mechanical microenvironment independent of cellular matrix production by applying mechanical stretch stimuli through 2D silicone membranes or compliant hydrogels bound to the silicone with custom methods. Molecular biology assays and protein expression analyses will help us determine which cell types are responding to mechanical signals through which pathways. Development of a model to control fibrosis may be one of the secrets to successful regeneration in mammals.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The Spiny Mouse is the only known mammal that can perfectly regenerate skin after extensive damage. This project studied Spiny Mouse cells in order to better understand how we may transfer this remarkable healing capability to humans. Enabled by the support of this project, we made three major contributions:

(1) We observed, for the first time, cells from mammals that have behavior opposite to all similar cells observed for the last 30 years. Our continued investigation of "broken" mechanisms in Spiny Mouse cells causing this behavior has the potential to direct the entire field toward new mechanisms that may one day be targeted by drugs.

(2) A key development in this project and the entire field of regenerative medicine is that we have immortalized Spiny Mouse cells so that we may conduct larger experiments more rapidly without using animals for research. We also demonstrated that these immortalized cells are similar to primary cells for up to 30 passages. This progress enables us to share cells with collaborators and other researchers interested in regenerative medicine and reduce the number of animals used from research.

(3) We have identified proteins and genes that are different between Spiny Mouse and normal mouse cells in certain environments, which will support future development of drugs for wound healing. We used analysis of RNA to identify ~130 genes of interest that affect the rebuilding of skin and ~20 genes that affect the recruitment of immune cells to wounds.

We also made sure to communicate the results of this project to the broader scientific community. The professors, graduate students, and undergraduate students working on this project traveled to numerous national and international conferences to present their work a total of 17 times. We published the results in respected journals for a total of 7 papers by the beginning of 2022, with an additional four papers under review and in preparation. These papers have already been cited over 70 times, meaning they have been important to the work of over 70 other groups.

In addition to the scientific contributions from this project, we have contributed extensively to building the next generation of scientists and engineers. Nine graduate students and 12 undergraduate students were directly trained in research and related techniques through this project.  We also trained two K-12 teachers and two high school students in research and related techniques through this project. An additional 61 students were trained via coursework inspired by this project.

Taken together, this project enabled important advances in our understanding of skin regeneration and trained the next generation to continue this important work.


Last Modified: 04/25/2022
Modified by: Chelsey Simmons
